Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the effectiveness of N95 masks in blocking COVID-19 particles by stating that they block few, if any, particles.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient scientific evidence or support to back up the assertion that N95 masks are ineffective in blocking COVID-19 particles.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the size of the COVID-19 particle alone determines the effectiveness of N95 masks, without considering the fact that the virus is always bonded to larger particles.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts scientific studies and expert opinions that demonstrate the effectiveness of N95 masks in filtering particles, including those smaller than 0.3 microns.
Understate: The claim understates the efficiency of N95 masks in filtering particles smaller than 0.3 microns, failing to acknowledge their electrostatic attraction to mask fibers.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the effectiveness of N95 masks, such as the filtration of larger particles that carry COVID-19 particles.
